content: These are lists of the most common [Chinese surnames](/wiki/Chinese_surname) in the [People's Republic of China](/wiki/China) ([Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong), [Macau](/wiki/Macau), and [Mainland China](/wiki/Mainland_China)), the [Republic of China (Taiwan)](/wiki/Taiwan), and the [Chinese diaspora](/wiki/Overseas_Chinese) overseas as provided by government or academic sources. [Chinese names](/wiki/Chinese_name) also form the basis for many common [Cambodian](/wiki/Lists_of_most_common_surnames_in_Asian_countries#Cambodia), [Japanese](/wiki/List_of_common_Japanese_surnames), [Korean](/wiki/List_of_Korean_surnames), and [Vietnamese surnames](/wiki/Lists_of_most_common_surnames_in_Asian_countries#Vietnam), and to an extent, [Filipino surnames](/wiki/Lists_of_most_common_surnames_in_Asian_countries#Philippines) in both translation and transliteration into those languages. The conception of China as consisting of the "[old hundred families](/wiki/Baixing)" ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 老百姓; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Lǎo Bǎi Xìng*; lit. 'Old Hundred Surnames') is an ancient and traditional one, the most notable tally being the [Song](/wiki/Song_dynasty)-era *[Hundred Family Surnames](/wiki/Hundred_Family_Surnames)* ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 百家姓; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Bǎi Jiā Xìng*). Even today, the number of surnames in China is a little over 4,000, while the [2000 United States census](/wiki/2000_United_States_census) found there are more than 6.2 million surnames altogether and that the number of surnames held by 100 or more Americans (per name) was just over 150,000. The Chinese expression "Three [Zhang](/wiki/Zhang_(surname)) Four [Li](/wiki/Li_(surname_%E6%9D%8E))" ([simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 张三李四; [traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 張三李四; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Zhāng Sān Lǐ Sì*) is used to mean "anyone" or "everyone", but the most common surnames are currently [Wang](/wiki/Wang_(surname)) in [mainland China](/wiki/Mainland_China) and [Chen](/wiki/Chen_(surname)) in [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan). A commonly cited [factoid](/wiki/Factoid) from the 1990 edition of the *[Guinness Book of World Records](/wiki/Guinness_Book_of_World_Records)* estimated that Zhang was the most common surname in the world, but no comprehensive information from China was available at the time and more recent editions have not repeated the claim. However, [Zhang Wei](/wiki/Zhang_Wei_(disambiguation)) (张伟) is the most common *full* name in mainland China. The top five surnames in China – Wang, Li, Zhang, Liu, Chen – are also the top five surnames in the world, each with over 70-100 million worldwide. ## China This list of the 100 most common [Chinese surnames](/wiki/Chinese_surname) derives from China's [Ministry of Public Security](/wiki/Ministry_of_Public_Security_(China))'s annual report on the top 100 surnames in China, with the latest report release in January 2020 for the year 2019. When the [1982 Chinese census](/wiki/1982_Chinese_census) was first published, it did not include a list of top surnames. However, in 2004, the [State Post Bureau](/wiki/State_Post_Bureau) subsequently used the census data to release a series of commemorative stamps in honor of the then-most-common surnames in 2004. The summary of the 2007 survey revealed China had approximately 92,881,000 [Wangs](/wiki/Wang_(surname)) (7.25% of the population), 92,074,000 [Lis](/wiki/Li_(surname_%E6%9D%8E)) (7.19%), and 87,502,000 [Zhangs](/wiki/Zhang_(surname)) (6.83%). A 2018 survey showed that [Liu](/wiki/Liu_(surname)) and [Chen](/wiki/Chen_(surname)) were the next most common China with more than 70 million each. These top five surnames – Wang, Lee (Li), Zhang, Liu, Chen – alone accounted for more people than [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), the fourth most populous country in the world, The next five – [Yang](/wiki/Yang_(surname)), [Huang](/wiki/Huang_(surname)), [Zhao](/wiki/Zhao_(surname)), [Wu](/wiki/Wu_(surname)), and [Zhou](/wiki/Zhou_(surname)) – were each shared by more than 20 million Chinese. Twelve more – [Xu](/wiki/Xu_(surname_%E5%BE%90)), [Sun](/wiki/Sun_(surname)), [Ma](/wiki/Ma_(surname)), [Zhu](/wiki/Zhu_(surname)), [Hu](/wiki/Hu_(surname)), [Guo](/wiki/Guo_(surname)), [He](/wiki/He_(surname)), [Gao](/wiki/Gao_(surname)), [Lin](/wiki/Lin_(surname)), [Luo](/wiki/Luo_(surname)), [Zheng](/wiki/Zheng_(surname)), and [Liang](/wiki/Liang_(surname)) – were each shared by more than 10 million. All together, the top hundred surnames accounted for 84.77% of China's population. ### Surname list This article may **require cleanup** to meet Wikipedia's quality standards. 1994–2011: The American researcher Chih-Hao Tsai has compiled unauthoritative annual surveys of the most common surnames on Taiwan based on published lists of all successful applicants taking Taiwan's Joint College Entrance Exam. The test was mandatory for college entrance until 2002 and is still quite common, with more than a hundred thousand successful applicants a year and a pass rate for all test takers between 60 and 90%. ## Philippines [Chinese Filipinos](/wiki/Chinese_Filipino) whose ancestors came to the Philippines from 1898 onward usually have single syllable Chinese surnames. On the other hand, most who have Chinese ancestors who came to the Philippines prior to 1898 usually have multiple-syllable Chinese surnames such as Cuyegkeng, Gokongwei, Ongpin, CuUnjieng, Pempengco, Yuchengco, Teehankee, Tansipek, and Yaptinchay among such others. These were originally full [Chinese names](/wiki/Chinese_name) which were transliterated in [Spanish](/wiki/Philippine_Spanish) orthography and adopted as surnames. Common Chinese Filipino surnames are: Tan/Chan ([陳/陈](/wiki/Chen_(surname))), Dy/Dee/Lee/Li ([李](/wiki/Li_(surname_%E6%9D%8E))), Sy/See/Siy/Sze ([施](/wiki/Sh%C4%AB_(surname))), Lim/Lam ([林](/wiki/Lin_(surname))), Chua/Choa/Choi ([蔡](/wiki/Cai_(surname))), Yap/Ip ([葉/叶](/wiki/Ye_(surname))), Co/Ko/Kho ([許/许](/wiki/Xu_(surname_%E8%A8%B1))), Ko/Gao/Caw ([高](/wiki/Gao_(surname))), Ho/Haw/Hau/Caw ([侯](/wiki/Hou_(surname))), Cua/Kua/Co/Kho/Ko ([柯](/wiki/Ke_(surname))), Coo/Gu/Ku/Khu/Cu ([邱](/wiki/Qi%C5%AB_(surname))), Go/Ngo/Wu ([吳/吴](/wiki/Wu_(surname))), Ong/Wong ([王](/wiki/Wang_(surname))), Ang/Hong/Hung ([洪](/wiki/Ang_(surname))), Lao ([劉/刘](/wiki/Liu)), Tiu/Cheung ([張/张](/wiki/Zhang_(surname))), Yu/Young ([楊/杨](/wiki/Yang_(surname))), Auyong/Awyoung ([歐陽/欧阳](/wiki/Ouyang)), Ng/Uy/Wee/Hong/Wong/Huang ([黃](/wiki/Huang_(surname))), Tiu/Chiu/Chio/Chu ([趙/赵](/wiki/Zhao_(surname))), Chu/Chiu/Chow ([周](/wiki/Zhou_(surname))), King ([龔](/wiki/Gong_(surname))), Chan ([曾](/wiki/Zeng)), Ty/Tee ([鄭/郑](/wiki/Zheng_(surname))), Ching/Cheng/Chong ([莊/庄](/wiki/Zhuang_(surname))), Que/Cue/Kwok ([郭](/wiki/Guo)), Leong/Liong/Leung ([梁](/wiki/Liang_(surname))), etc. There are also multiple-syllable Chinese surnames that are Spanish transliterations of [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) words. Surnames like Tuazon (eldest grandson, 大孫), Dizon (second grandson, 二孫), Samson/Sanson (third grandson, 三孫), Sison (fourth grandson, 四孫), Guzon/Gozum/Gozon/Goson (fifth grandson, 五孫), Lacson (sixth grandson, 六孫), Tecson/Ticzon/Tiongson/Teoxon (seventh grandson, 德孫/提克宗/頂客/东阳顺), Sioson (eighth grandson, 西奥森) and Hizon (ninth grandson, 希森) are examples of transliterations of designations that use the Hokkien suffix -son (孫) used as surnames for some Chinese Filipinos who trace their ancestry from Chinese immigrants to the Philippines during the Spanish colonial period. The surname "Timkang" (添康) is listed in the Chinese text *[Hundred Family Surnames](/wiki/Hundred_Family_Surnames)*, perhaps shedding light on the Hokkien suffix -Kang used here as a surname alongside some sort of accompanying enumeration scheme. Just as in Thailand, though, previous legislation (in this case, [127/U/Kep/12/1966](/wiki/127/U/Kep/12/1966)) had banned ethnic Chinese surnames throughout the country. This law was abolished after the removal of [Suharto](/wiki/Suharto), but [Chinese Indonesian names](/wiki/Chinese_Indonesian_names) remain a mix of [Indonesian](/wiki/Indonesian_name), [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin), [pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB), and Dutch-spelled Hokkien. ## Malaysia During the [2010 Malaysian Census](/wiki/2010_Malaysian_Census), there were approximately 6,960,000 Malaysians of Chinese ethnicity. The Chinese are the second largest ethnicity in Malaysia, after the Malays. ## Singapore [Ethnic Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_Singaporeans) make up almost three-fourths (2009) of Thais](/wiki/Chinese_Thai) (or Sino-Thais), who make up 12–14% of the total Thai population. However, very few Chinese Thais have Chinese surnames, after the 1913 Surname Act that required the adoption of Thai surnames in order to enjoy Thai citizenship. Moreover, the same law requires that those possessing the same surname be related, meaning that immigrant Chinese may not adopt the surname of their clansmen unless they can show actual kinship. ## United States The [2010 US Census](/wiki/2010_US_Census) found 3,794,673 self-identified [Chinese Americans](/wiki/Chinese_American) and 230,382 self-identified [Taiwanese Americans](/wiki/Taiwanese_American), up from 2,734,841 [Chinese Americans](/wiki/Chinese_American) and 144,795 [Taiwanese Americans](/wiki/Taiwanese_American) in 2000. Although the [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese-American) make up the largest segment of the U.S. [Asian and Pacific Islander](/wiki/Asian_and_Pacific_Islander) population, the most common Chinese-derived surname during the [2000 census](/wiki/2000_US_census) was not itself Chinese but the Vietnamese [Nguyễn](/wiki/Nguyen_(surname)) ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 阮, *Ruǎn*).
